title: Building This Portfolio With Svelte
description: How I built this entire portfolio site using SvelteKit — from dynamic blogs to smooth routing, and why Svelte just clicks.
fullContent:
So I Needed a Portfolio

Every developer hits that point where they need an actual portfolio site. Not just a GitHub profile or a LinkedIn page — something that actually feels like yours.

I wanted something clean, fast, and not a nightmare to maintain.

That's where Svelte came in.

Why Svelte Over React or Vue?

I've worked with React before. It's solid. But honestly? The boilerplate gets exhausting.

Svelte just... makes sense. Less code. No virtual DOM overhead. Actual reactivity without weird hooks.

Plus, SvelteKit handles routing, SSR, and all the framework stuff without feeling like you're configuring webpack for three hours.

The Structure: Keeping It Simple

The site is split into sections:

  • Main landing section
  • About me
  • Skills
  • Timeline (work & education)
  • Projects showcase
  • Blog (yeah, the one you're reading right now)
  • Contact

Each section lives in its own component. No monolithic files. Just clean separation.

SvelteKit's file-based routing makes this stupid easy. Want a /blogs page? Just create src/routes/blogs/+page.svelte. Done.

Dynamic Blogs Using JSON

Originally, I hardcoded blog data into the page. Bad idea.

Then I moved everything into JSON files inside static/blogs/. Now the blog page dynamically loads all JSON files at runtime.

Add a new blog? Just drop a JSON file in that folder. No need to touch the code.

const blogFiles = import.meta.glob('/static/blogs/*.json');
const blogPromises = Object.entries(blogFiles).map(async ([path, resolver]) => {
  const response = await fetch(path.replace('/static', ''));
  return await response.json();
});
blogs = await Promise.all(blogPromises);

Simple. Works. Scales.

Component Structure That Actually Makes Sense

Everything lives under src/lib/:

  • components/blog/ — blog cards and layouts
  • components/layout/ — navbar, footer
  • components/project/ — project cards
  • sections/ — major page sections

Svelte's scoped styles mean I don't need CSS modules or some convoluted naming system. Styles stay where they belong — in the component.

What I Actually Like About Svelte

Reactivity just works. No useState, no useEffect. Just:

let count = 0;
$: doubled = count * 2;

That's it. doubled updates automatically when count changes.

No mental gymnastics. No dependency arrays. Just logic.

Deployment? Ridiculously Easy

SvelteKit builds everything into static files. Host it anywhere — Vercel, Netlify, GitHub Pages, wherever.

No server required. Just pure static HTML, CSS, and JS.

Fast. Simple. Works everywhere.

What I'd Do Differently Next Time

Honestly? Not much.

Maybe use a headless CMS instead of JSON files if the blog scales. But for now, JSON works perfectly fine.

I might also add transitions between pages. SvelteKit supports that natively, I just haven't gotten around to it yet.

Final Thoughts

Building this site with Svelte was genuinely enjoyable.

No framework fatigue. No config hell. Just clean code that does what it's supposed to do.

If you're building something similar — a portfolio, a blog, whatever — give Svelte a shot.

You might actually have fun doing it.
